author: Jonesboro

description.text:
Many times I find myself searching for that perfect universal vertex.  Each geometry may or may not have one of those.
This thing is the universal vertex for making rectangular things.
It's fairly simple.  Just a cube with holes that go all the way through on each of the axes.  The default size here will allow you to screw 5/16 threaded rod through it.
It is very handy when you're trying to construct a closed space using threaded rod without a turn buckle.  You can simply thread it through the end.
It's a fairly straight forward print, although depending on how your printer deals with support, a design that uses tear drops in the holes might be easier.
Perhaps another design that has even less material in contact with the raft will make it even better, and more aesthetically pleasing.

1) Print a few of these
2) Thread rods through them to form a rectangular shape
3) Rejoice!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/eXnYaSBSoVz

After a 3D scanning section with the client, the model has been finished on CAD software in order to be able to the printout job.   
Printing was made with ABS, with raft and no supports.

http://discuss-learn.media.mit.edu/t/dice4scratch-test-and-enjoy/1395 This is a project initially started by CyberParra in the Learning Creative Learning (LCL) online community at the MIT MediaLab. The idea is a set of basic and advanced dice, where players take random dice results to craft a simple and unique Scratch project in 10 minutes. You can learn more about the resources and inspiration here: CyberParra's project thread: http://discuss-learn.media.mit.edu/t/dice4scratch-test-and-enjoy/1395 Scratch: http://scratch.mit.edu/ LCL: http://learn.media.mit.edu/ We do not own Scratch or LCL, this is a free and open source creative learning educational resource by fans and community members of LCL and Scratch. For the laser cutter designs, we used the Tabbed Box plugin for Inkscape and a custom Knox Makers Inkscape plugin for use with our own laser cutter. I left the SVG images as solid black outline, but for etching our laser cutter uses #00ffffff and #0000ffff. Images used are altered images of the visual programming blocks in the Scratch graphical programming interface. You can find the original plans for CyberParra's PDF to print out and make handmade dice, too.

title: (moved) SteadyCam Mark I
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/steadycam-mark-ii Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html This gimbal converts a sturdy car-mount for a laptop/camera into a steadycam. The current version does not have a bearing for the vertical axis, so you can turn the camera by attaching a large handle to the side (use both hands to control the orientation of the camera). TODO: I did not yet asssemble it fully, to check if it is stable enough for the serious weight of the car-mount. It's a work in progress and my internet is not very good on this train, so I'll describe it in more detail later. Details:
http://sourceforge.net/userapps/mediawiki/marcuswolschon/index.php?title=Projects/Camera/Steadycam ----------------------------------------------
V0.2:
Status:
Was found to be too large. Something with the meassurements was off.
Probably specified diameter as radius or something. Build time: (16mm/s, 0.4mm layers, 20% filled, 3 solid layers)
inner: 2h 34min (28.7g of ABS)
outher: 3h (33.8g of ABS)
grib: 13h 21min (155.2g of ABS) ----------------------------------------------
V0.2:
changes:
  • grib is M22, fits bicycle-handle
  • inner has the right size
  • cleaned up the constraints on the grib
    Build time: (16mm/s, 0.4mm layers, 20% filled, 3 solid layers)
    inner half: 29min (5.4g of ABS)
    outher: 1h25min (16g of ABS)
    grib: 5h (57.6g of ABS)
    ----------------------------------------------
    V0.3:
    Some minor improvements for easier fitting but Alibre crashes reproducably on save. Will take a wile.
    ----------------------------------------------
    V0.4:
    reconstructed "inner" from scratch.
  • better grib on bearing
  • easier insertion of bearing
  • tapper against inaccurate diameter due to melting first layer
    • Build time: (16mm/s, 0.4mm layers, 20% filled, 3 solid layers)
    inner half: 36min (6.8g of ABS)
    ----------------------------------------------
    V0.5/v0.6:
    less snug fit on shaft, bearing and bolts, shorter grip.
    TODO: I am not sure if the "outher" ring is thick enough to support the weight. Build time: (16mm/s, 0.4mm layers, 20% filled, 3 solid layers)
    inner half: 38min (7.1g of ABS)
    outher: 1h 36min (18.3g of ABS)
    grip: 4h (45g of ABS)
    ----------------------------------------------
    V0.7:
    Status: considered a working prototype
    outher did not fit, too much linear play between bearing and next part.
    Made sure all diameters are matching with 1mm distance on bearings and 2mm rotational against collisions.
    Added a 1/4" hole to mount a camera-handle on the side (for both, left and right handed users) to control the horizontal turning of the camera. Build time: (16mm/s, 0.4mm layers, 20% filled, 3 solid layers)
    inner both: 1h 23min (15.6g of ABS)
    outher: 1h 37min (18.5g of ABS)
    grip: 4h (45.7g of ABS)
    ----------------------------------------------
    V0.8 and SteadyCam Mark II:
    Status: work in progress
    changes:
  • moved handle below the center of gravity
  • handle can rotate freely

See
https://sourceforge.net/userapps/mediawiki/marcuswolschon/index.php?title=Projects/Camera/Steadycam
for the assembly.
There is a discussion about this at
http://hbsboard.com/index.php?topic=4931.msg42798#msg42798 Abstract: First make sure the bolts fit into the 608 bearings. Then glue them into their holes. Do not attach the bolts yet. You may need a bit of blunt force. Not too far in, make sure the 608 rotate freely. The 2 halfs of the inner ring go around the extended inner shaft of the car-mount just below the head. Then add the nuts and the outher ring. You need to disassemble the upper turning joint (see photo) and remove the nut from the slide-out fastener (see photo) to move "outher" into position.
The M8 nuts are supposed to cut their own threading into the ABS for a good, tight fit. Then the "grip".
Attach a bicycle-handle to the grip for added comfort.

author: MarcusWolschon

description.text:
Simple project box - Can be printed on the MakerBot Mini  
--- Revised STL file output for highest resolution printing --

After I built my Kossel mini with 1515 extrusions I felt the recirculating ball carriages were too tight and I wanted to build new carriages with stuff I have or could get locally. I like having 4 wheels instead of the usual 3 wheel designs. The 4 wheel design was also dictated a little by the smaller Prime Line wheels I found at Home Depot. I don't think there's any more wiggle in the carriage then there was with the recirculating carriages which was very rigid and stable (possibly because it was so tight). The new carriage moves more easily with the wheels compared to the delrin ball carriages. I  did lose a cm or so of build height because the traxxas mounts are a little lower than standard. I might move them higher in a later version, but I'm just happy to have it printing so I'm not sure I'll get around to that. Besides, mechanically I feel better about them being between the mounting screws. It seems more secure and less susceptible to any warping of the print.   
There's a photo of the wheels and screws I bought at home depot. Prime Line M-6000: 12 wheels are about $12 and the #8-32 1inch screws are 8 per bag so I bought 2 bags for $1.18 each but only 12 are used in the build. I had a bunch of 22mm m3 cap screws and m3 nylon lock nuts from a previous project so I used 18 screws and 12 lock nuts and 6 standard m3 nuts. So for $15 plus tax it was a nice little upgrade. It will cost you more if you have to buy the M3 screws and nuts. The model could be modified easily to accommodate more common screws like 25mm.  
Hope this helps someone out there.

Printed in PLA 0.3mm layer height, 30% hexagonal infill and 3 layer walls.  
Assembly is pretty straight forward. There are nut traps for everything so you shouldn't have to hold any of the nuts with a wrench while tightening. There are slots on the side to insert a standard m3 nut for the tensioning screw. Usually i put those in and thread in the tension screw to secure them loosely first thing so i know if that tunnel printed well. It's probably the most likely detail to print incorrectly if your printer doesn't bridge well. Next, screw on the wheels and finally the traxxas carriages. the tension screws don't need lock nuts because i made the hole past the nut smaller so it should act as the lock.

Ok - you may have figured out my like of rockets... Hmm..
So, this is a rocket you can laser cut and stick on your wall! I saw a photo of a rocket similar to this some time ago, so I had a go at making my own. I think mine looks better :)

The file contains two parts - the top layer with the holes and the lower layer which is solid. I cut this one from 3mm MDF. You could also cut from acrylic, ply or even cardboard :) 
From tip to tail, it's 530mm long!
I painted the lower layer matt black and the top layer red with a light over-spray of titanium silver flake. I also off-set the two parts (once painted) to give the illusion of a drop shaddow.
Use wood glue to stick together.

remixed_from.title: Equilateral Triangle with a linear extruded frame

description.text:
Its a triangle, twisted, extruded and supported inside and out.  
There is actually a lot going on with this design but it has been incremental, so enjoy!  
Please scale down to fit your printer dimensions but I found 25% scale of original is VERY strong.  
Added a second copy of the scad file. (less comment)  
Final Version is updated with vectors and modules. MUCH cleaner and easier to read. Also, much easier to modify and create with.

wanting to learn more about linear extrusion, I downloaded a twisted box stl file. However, I wanted only the wire frame. So I applied the linear extrusion code to my extruded triangle openscad file. This created a nicer to look at extrusion but easily breakable design.
(twist oppose the extrusion) So I added 'inner' pillars to help support the midpoints of the triangle. (offsetting offsets with trig is interesting) Lastly, I reversed the 'polarity' (?) of the inner pillars to see what happens. Wow. From being flimsy with an achilles heel to being structural sound, what a difference a negative sign can make.

title: Square Reader Symmetric Clip and Protector

description.text: Square users, rejoice!

Are you tired of swipe errors because of your Reader spinning? Well, no more! This clip prevents your Reader from spinning out of control! In addition to keeping the Reader stable, it also helps protect the TRRS connector, allowing you to throw your Reader into a bag without worry. This clip works with the current 3rd generation Square Reader released in late 2013, the flat one without the internal battery. I have tested and can confirm it works with the following devices (without a case, of course):
Samsung Galaxy S III
Samsung Galaxy Note 3
iPhone 4/4S UPDATE:
Added 8mm version that should fit thinner devices, such as iPhone 5/5S/6/6 Plus, iPad Air, and iPad Mini. If you find that it also works other devices, please let me know :) The opening for the device side is 10mm with the hole placed in the center. I am also including the original IPT file in case you would like to widen it to fit your device. Print with support and standing up.

description.text:
From the record sleeve to the player and then what? They're not many stands available for the vinyl itself out there. Inspired by Ghostly International's individuality, high art and unconventional sleeve art, the proposal presents both a vinyl stand and conversation piece.   
Either for cleaning or temporarily storing or showcasing vinyls, the stand holds vinyl records without touching the groove. When not in use, the stand looks like a piece of art.

Two files are available.
Ghostly vinyl stand is optimized for Makerbots and easy printing.
Recommended settings:
0.1mm to 0.25mm layer height, 10% infill, no support needed. Raft recommended. If you're familiar with tinkering with 3d printing, perimeter settings, top and bottom layers, etc. You can also download shell only file for experimentation and more freedom in terms of thickness and infills.

This is a thing i made in my spare time. this is my first make so leave a comment and rate fairly.

After destroying several plastic belts in silly experiments, I needed a cheaper and quicker way of sourcing replacements. There's nothing cheaper and quicker than making your own with kapton tape and paper! I think it works even better than the plastic belts because of better adhesion and less surface warping. Works with the Cupcake's ABP V1.0 and on the Thing-O-Matic's ABP (although you quickly get wrinkles in the middle because of the roller gap)

1) Take a Makerbot supplied, ABP plastic parallelogram belt and lay it on a sheet of paper. A4 is enough for the Cupcake APB but something bigger is needed for the Thingomatic.
2) Mark the corners with a pen and connect the dots to create an outline.
3) Use 20mm wide kapton tape (or wider) to cover up the area within the outline.
4) Cut out the outline to make a parallelogram belt.
5) Proceed as you would with a Makerbot supplied, ABP parallelogram belt. ^^;

comments.text:
Instead of using paper, I constructed one of Tyvek (TM) and Kapton (TM) tape on top... According to DuPont's specs, "Tyvek Olefin begins to shrink at approximately 270
Ã‚Â°F (132Ã‚Â°C) and melts at 275Ã‚Â°F (135Ã‚Â°C). Under actual processing conditions, where tension is required to handle the web, the web temperature should not exceed 175Ã‚Â°F (79Ã‚Â°C)." Since the ABP should be under the 175F limit, this might be OK. You can get the Tyvek as "house wrap" at a building sup
ply place or maybe even recycle an envelope made of it. Thing is, it is rather indestructable, doesn't absorb moisture, and doesn't warp with tension. Probably will rough up the surface a bit with 600 or 1000 grit paper. It certainly runs smoothly on the ABP, so off to test it with a build. I ha
ve a set of pictures with instructions here: http://picasaweb.google.com/EricAlbertPhD/ABPBeltConstruction?feat=directlinkhttp://picasaweb.google.com/Er...

description.text: Sam Cohn was an exuberant boy with a 1000 watt smile. He loved his friends, family, dog, and bird deeply. Sam was passionate about guitar, snowboarding, lacrosse, and having fun. Sam was born on May 28, 1992. He was hit by a car on November 20, 2006 in Florida while visiting friends. His beautiful body stayed strong long enough for organ donation. He gave his heart, liver, kidney, and kidney-pancreas so that four others would live. His spirit continues on through them and surrounds us today. Sam lived his life to its fullest on this planet. t is hard to capture Sam's true spirit in a few paragraphs. He taught us so much. Mostly he taught us to have fun, ease up, and to be there for each other. He is a true best friend to many and deeply missed. SamStones are made with love. They are small fired clay rocks that have Sam's name and our website on them. You can read about them at http://samstones.org. We make these stones by hand in community gatherings where we all come togetrher to have fun and to heal. We give the stones out to anyone who wants them and invite them to keep them, pass them on or place them in a special place. We hope tht anyone who finds a SamStone picks up a little of Sam's joyous spirit . We also hope they find their way to theis website where thhye can tell us about where they found the stone and/or where they placed it. title: Kris Kringle Christmas Chaos
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Kris Kringle Christmas Chaos is an animated whimsical Christmas themed centerpiece. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9N1GamLkD90&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill) settings.

Parts I purchased:  
1) 6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8" (amazon).  
2) Coaxial Power Jack (Radio Shack part number 274-1583).  
3) 3.0 Vdc Power Supply (Radio Shack part number 273-315 with the "N" style plug 273-345, you get one free with the power supply).  
Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp".  For "Chimney Front.stl", "Chimney Back.stl" and "Chimney Side.stl", I started the print in grey, paused the printer at 2.2 mm, changed color to red, then un-paused the printer.  The grey color gives the appearance of mortar between the bricks.  I then hand colored the ends of the protruding bricks with red (I used an indelible ink marker).  
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  
Assemble as per "Assembly.skp".  
Wiring is pretty straight forward, however you'll need soldering skills and equipment. Basically, solder a 6" red wire between the gear motor "plus" terminal and the coaxial power jack "Center" terminal, then solder a 6" black wire between the gear motor "minus" terminal and the coaxial power jack "Shield" terminal. Make sure the wires do not interfere with moving components.  
Lubricate moving surfaces with light machine oil.  
Comment if questions.  
Hope you like it!

Acrylic protective case for BeagleBoard Black boards. Allows for safe handling while keeping connections exposed. Button holes and extenders are included. That things that looks like galaxian ships (drawn at the ethernet and power conector cutouts) are springed test buttons, designed to avoid rattling noise when the board is shaken. I could not getit working so I ended up using the simpler version (drawn at the USB cutout). Prototype version on the photos had the folowing issues:
  • Miscounted j1 pins, hadto hack an extra cut while fabricating.
  • Excessive clearance from power jack.
  • Insufficient clearance from C34.
    Sources are fixed, but untested.

This .blend file is designed to assist people in properly fitting 3d-printed prosthetic devices to clients based on photos. This work is for you. Please comment if there's anything you need, like models you'd like me to add and set up. This file includes the following models: (from left to right)
The Cyborg Beast
The Talon Hand 3.0
The Ody Hand 2.0
The Raptor Hand
The Raptor Reloaded
The Osprey Hand
The Flexy Hand 2
The Phoenix Hand
The K-1 Hand Models for 30x30 centimeter grids and 12x12 inch grids in the top and side view help with the scaling process. Please follow the Youtube video tutorial series in the instructions to learn the image scaling process.

Here is the 21-minute course for how to use this file. Don't skip any steps!
The image has to be properly scaled in the Blender frame, or the device will not fit properly.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBHsuyNYSpxs4Xqj4_kzcbBiSby2tKqrH
This series is broken into four parts. The first is taking good orthographic photos of the client:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ewdC3BVUNmg
The second part shows how to navigate the Blender scene. I didn't make this video myself.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yC5UnF1tCHE
The third part teaches you how to import, scale and position photos into the background in Blender.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ylc5LobLSCY
The fourth and final part teaches you how to overlay and position a design assembly over client anatomy to determine the best scale to print the device.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DnDBFyF1qyU Please write comments. How can I improve this resource?

description.text: EDIT... I also just added a new file CTC1, this is a remix of a front panel that IAmOrion mixed from some of my parts as well. It's a lot nicer but requires some modding and drilling if you want to install one of these. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1421650 I couldn't stand having to get the right viewing angle on this printer so i made a mount for the LCD to angle it out. I used the front bezel from another item on Thingiverse and made new sides and a bottom. The bottom just gets glued on after assembly. Remove the display from the printer, install captive nuts in the slots on the sides, install the sides to the printer using the original display mounting holes and the original hardware. You will need four additional M3 nuts and four M3x20mm screws, maybe a bit shorter but thats what i had. Rest the LCD onto the sides and then put on the front bezel, install the longer screws through the front bezel and LCD into the captive nuts. Finally just glue the bottom on, i used a little bit of superglue on the edges and just pressed on the bottom and held it for a bit to set up. I thought about captive nuts and screws for installing the bottom, maybe in a later revision, this way was fast and easy to print and install. There is quite a few good covers for the hole that is left where the display was inside in the bottom of the printer, i'm working on making one though. EDIT- Just added a nice little cap to fill in the hole. Had to be tall enough to clear the nuts and washers for mounting the display enclosure so its a little taller than i had hoped but the fit is good and it keeps stuff from falling through!

Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.6 million polygons). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.
An experimental design for wargaming. More designs: http://makergames.net/

title: Torus for iPhone home 3d printing model set 1

description.text:
OpenGL video game objects adapted to FDM printing. Torus for iPhone is a free download available now on the iTunes App Store at http://uplink.to/73w These models were first 3D printed by using SLS (see photos). The text was too small to be legibly printed by FDM so the text was moved from the side (OK with selective laser sintering) to the top and enlarged for the FDM process. The score value side text on the tori was also too small for FDM so it was converted to roman numerals. Each Torus represents an attained high score in the game. torusFDM_III.stl - 3000 points
torusFDM_VI.stl - 6000 points
torusFDM_IX.stl - 9000 points
torusFDM_XII.stl - 12000 points The highest recorded Torus for iPhone score was 14800 on April 24th, 2009. The Shapeways version of the Torus Base Hook can be purchased at http://shpws.me/mQ2R - Torus high score Shapeways 3D printed tori models can only be purchased via Torus for iPhone when a score achievement is unlocked. Visit http://www.playtorus.com for more information. Torus dimensions: 40mm x 40mm x 14mm
Base dimensions: 50mm x 50mm x 17mm

Preparing the base hook for fused deposition modeling presented two main problems. The size of the text was just too small for the extruder on my Printrbot jr, and printing a vertical post ended up a blob of molten plastic without enough time for each layer to cool before depositing the next one. The first solution was to develop a model with two seperate posts, so that a short time would pass for a layer to cool as the extruder moved to the other side, I moved them as far apart on the base as possible to maximize this cooling period. This solution is embodied in the model torusFDM_Base2.stl The solution to getting a single post to print was explained to me at a TechShop Makerbot class in San Francisco - once the model has been sliced, edit the gcode to move the extruder away briefly per layer. The gcode file is a flat sequential text file, the instructions for the first layer are at the beginning of the file, with the last layer instructions being at the end. So I was able to find where the solo post codes were and added G1 X0.0 Y0.0 at the end of each layer. This solution is in torusFDM_Base_edited.gcode You can see a short video of the extruder of my Printrbot jr moving to XY home every layer as it prints the post at http://uplink.to/7e0 The gcode was generated by Slic3r 0.9.7 with the parameters shown here, from a Printrbot jr config file ; layer_height = 0.3
; perimeters = 2
; top_solid_layers = 3
; bottom_solid_layers = 2
; fill_density = 0.7
; perimeter_speed = 30
; infill_speed = 60
; travel_speed = 130
; scale = 1
; nozzle_diameter = 0.5
; filament_diameter = 3.00
; extrusion_multiplier = 1
; perimeters extrusion width = 0.70mm
; infill extrusion width = 0.70mm
; first layer extrusion width = 0.30mm Load this file directly instead of the STL file and print as usual, but beware it was sliced for a particular Printrbot jr setup and may not be appropriate for your local configuration. I also had a small fan blowing cold air over the print while the post layers were being deposited.

description.text:
This is a modification of the Prusa Air 2, modelled in FreeCAD. The purpose of this project was to make a Prusa Air-like reprap out of some old 10mm acrylic sheets I had lying around. I needed a simple design, with minimal curves, so that I could cut it by hand (no laser cutter).  
I designed from scratch, and (I think) strengthened the design, and removed the need for so many right angle brackets. The top plate now holds up the back plate, and is held down by the side plate. A bracked may be needed to stop the top plate from sliding forwards. The back plate now also has a carry handle at the top.
Bottom holes are in the same configuration as the Prusa Air. The top plate is a bit higher.

description.text:
UPDATED: you need to pause between reverse and forward commands. still working out why, exactly... This is for testing rapid reversal in gcode for RepRap, MakerBot, etc. It does a find and replace of M103 and M101 lines in your gcode file. Detailed instructions are in the top of the file. Use it like the following:
python RAPID_REVERSALify.py FILE.gcode printRPM reversalRPM waitTime
e.g.:
python RAPID_REVERSALify.py oozebane.gcode 2.857 25 200 you will get the printout:
we will print at 2.857 RPM
we will rapid reverse at 25.0 RPM
we will wait for 200 ms during rapid reversal and the file:
oozebane_RAPID_REVERSAL.gcode
will be created

First, every M103 command is replaced with:
M103 (Extruder off)
M108 R__REVERSAL_RPM
M102 (Extruder on, RAPID REVERSAL)
G04 P__WAIT_TIME (Wait t/1000 seconds)
M103 (Extruder off) Then, every M101 command is replaced with:
(reaccelerate to prev position)
M108 R__REVERSAL_RPM
M101 (Extruder on, RAPID FORWARD)
G04 P_WAIT_TIME (Wait t/1000 seconds)
M103 (Extruder off)
M108 R__PRINT_RPM
M101 (Extruder on, forward)

This is a two-piece adapter that allows a J-Head MkV to be securely mounted on the "Jigsaw Replacement Extruder mk3" by lawsy et al. It can also be used to mount the original Makergear-style hotend without the plywood plate (which I've always found rather inelegant anyway).  
Note that this design occupies the mounting bosses normally used for the accessory mounting system. Then again, now you have the plywood plate mounting holes at your disposal...

(If you haven't yet, print out the jigsaw extruder replacement:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40711 ) Print the model with fairly heavy fill. Have a sharp hobby knife handy for touch-ups. Test the fit of both pieces against the groove in the PEEK cylinder. They should fit fairly snugly and hug the outer radius.
Now test the fit of both pieces in the slot in the lower extruder piece. Again, they should be snug, but not so tight that you have to distort the extruder piece to get them in.
// I found that some very minor whittling was necessary to clean up the the features that grab the cylinder, mostly around the thin pointy bits at the sides (which came out slightly warped). Press-fit the small insert into the back of the lower extruder block, and [re-]mount it on the stepper motor. Slide the J-head into the slot and rotate it into the desired position, as it will not be able to rotate once clamped in. Finally, mount the front retainer piece: push it into the slot in the extruder, and secure it in place with self-tapping screws. You will probably end up with a gap of 0.5mm or so between the retainer bar and the face of the extruder. Verify that the retainer is properly seated against the insulator. For extra snugness you can tighten down the screws until the retainer bar bows ever-so-slightly, but this will likely cause some crazing on the front face. Important! Potential carriage crash!
After removing the plywood plate, you will likely find that there is nothing to trip the arm on your X limit switch. I got around this by extending the switch arm with some scrap material. A better solution would be to put a feature on the front retainer that reaches around to trip the switch. I will address this in a future revision. Enjoy printing with a hot-end that doesn't clog every time you look at it funny!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

In an effort to feed the cats consistent amounts, without overfeeding, I needed a 1/4-cup measuring cup. It felt silly to buy a whole pack of measuring cups just for the one, especially with a Replicator in the other room. I decided to design a measuring cup, instead. And while I was doing the math for the quarter-cup variant, it's easy enough to parameterize for other sizes. Go ahead and pick one of the predefined sizes (from 1/8 cup to 1 cup, in 1/8-cup increments) or pick "Custom" and enter some number of milliliters for anything in between. The design of each cup is such that the cup's width and height are equal. This better facilitates nesting them within one another, though the actual nestability is ultimately based on which sizes you have and how thick you make the wall. This is version 2 of the measuring cup (though the first public release). The original quarter-cup model had been in use for about a year until the handle broke. This version has a thicker, more stylized, handle plus added strain relief. More information on my blog at: http://netninja.com/2013/03/02/choose-your-own-measuring-cup/ â€Ž

Pick a predetermine size or enter your own.  Print with an infill of your choosing.  (I used the Replicator default because I'm using kibble, not liquid.  You may want a more dense infill.)  
The variables and calculations are well commented, so you should be able to understand what's going on if you peek into the OpenSCAD file.

title: Boscam HD-19 Mount for Tarot gimbal (T-2D V2)

description.text:
This camera mount allows you to mount the Boscam HD 19 camera directly into the tarot gibal designed for gopro hero 3 cameras.  
The design includes a pocket on top in order to put some weight in case needed.  
You can use some foam to keep the cammera tightly inside the case/mount.

Remove the original mount for the gopro hero and replace it with this mount. Use the same screw provided to fix the mount to the motor shaft.  
you can add some weight and put it in the pocket of the upper part of the mount.  
Some problems may occur with the gimbal stabilization. This can be solved by modifying the CG of the camera (adding weight) or by modifying the control parameters of the gimbal.  
The IMU was directly stuck to the rear of the cammera with double-sided tape.  
IMPORTANT: Print it with the front hole facing downwards.

NOTE: This isn't Thing-O-Matic compatible (which I found out). Had to build lip-edge holders as the ToM sits on the edges of the box rather than inside the box. Whole box needs to grow ~6mm in X & Y direction to properly fix ToM. Justsoyaknow... The original files are in EPS/DXF format, so I tweaked them up and laid them out in a CorelDraw X4 file for our 24x18" bed 60W Helix laser. During assembly, we found out the fingers are 2mm, not 4mm like the rest of the material, so the bottom disk slots have been suitably widened. UPDATE: The fingers suck even with 2mm. I snagged quite a few times, so we ended up redoing them first on 1/16" plywood, then our latest version uses loops of 3mm filament. Update coming. UPDATE - Feb 2011: The fingers still snapped. Redesigned to use "U" loops of filament instead. Also the T-slots are mostly still too small for 4-40 nuts (identified). Added assembly notes.
Cut out of 1/4" white & clear acrylic, 100% power, 6% speed, 5000 frequency
